thread.title: Girls Fencing: Bergen Tech wins first state championship, 14-13, over Columbia (PHOTOS and VIDEO)
thread.title_full: Girls Fencing: Bergen Tech wins first state championship, 14-13, over Columbia (PHOTOS and VIDEO)

author: Matt Bove
title: Girls Fencing: Bergen Tech wins first state championship, 14-13, over Columbia (PHOTOS and VIDEO)
text:
Complete Box Score Â» 
ROCKAWAY -- Coming into the NJSIAA girls state fencing final , the Columbia girls fencing program had more state championships (12) than Bergen Tech had years existing as a program, but the Knights were not going to let that dichotomy in history intimidate them. 
Top-seeded Bergen Tech prevailed in a back-and-forth final over sixth-seeded Columbia , 14-13, at Morris Hills High on Wednesday to win its first state championship since the program started about a decade ago 
"My blood pressure was probably 200 over 200," said Bergen Tech head coach Arash Safavi . "I've won state championships and tournament of championships with volleyball as an assistant coach at Fair Lawn, but to win it as a varsity coach, have an undefeated season and win every single major tournament; 'bliss' is the word I can use." 
"We were just going crazy," said senior Dana Chou . "We tripped up a little at a couple places, but once we got the winning touch we knew it was supposed to be ours and we did everything we needed to get this win." 
Despite only having one meet decided by fewer than 10 or fewer points this season, the undefeated Knights responded to the pressure of the moment and knew Columbia would give them all they could handle. 
The epee squad was only 3-6 overall for Bergen Tech, but Kaitlyn Gill scored a 5-3 victory to clinch the match with Bergen Tech ahead by a score of 13-12. 
It was a nip-and-tuck meet with the biggest lead by either team being a 5-3 early advantage by Columbia and a 13-11 edge for Bergen Tech. With the meet tied up, 11-11, consecutive wins by Madeleine Chang and Christine Choi at foil gave the Knights some breathing room. 
The sabre squad was on point for the Knights with Casey Chan and Chou sweeping their three bouts each. 
"It definitely felt like a culmination of the entire season," said senior Catherine McNamara . "We've fought in every single thing we've entered and we've had a really great season. So, it just felt like a nice end." 
Looking back from when they were freshmen, McNamara and Chou can vouch for just how far the senior class has come from when the group first started fencing and Bergen Tech did not even win a round in the state tournament. 
"We started at a much different place than we ended," said McNamara. "My freshman year we would struggle through dual meets throughout the season. It feels very fulfilling to get this far now, and know we really deserve it." 
"In our freshman year, people would say 'Bergen Tech', and there would not be much of a reaction," said Chou. "To come all the way from just another team to the best team in the state has been absolutely amazing. We could not have done it without the hard work of everybody on this team." 
When Safavi first took over the program six years ago he saw that there was talent, but the skills had to be molded and moved toward the right direction for the fencing team to reach its potential. 
"When I first took over, nobody really knew Bergen Tech had a fencing program -- and if they knew, they were like 'who cares?'," said Safavi. "The thing that boggles my mind is that Bergen Tech had great fencers and great athletes, but there was no structure to the program. It was not like a traditional varsity program." 
"I took what I learned from my high school coach and my college coach, and I applied that to fencing. I've turned it little by little to a true varsity program with organization, leadership and management." 
The state championship concluded a season in which Bergen Tech also won its first Santelli Tournament and the District 5 tournament. 
"It's really cool to know that it's such a young program, said McNamara. "We got so lucky with such amazing fencers. I think the stars aligned, but we put in so much hard work that it's just a long time coming." 
Marissa Viqueira was 3-0 for Columbia at foil and Isabelle Wendt was 3-0 at epee.
